PHASE ONE

The Story

Before we read, we need to understand the 'mood' of our novel. Let's find out what kind of story this is!

Moving to next section.

HOW TO: Identify Genre

Keyword Hunt: Scan 'About the Author' (p.144) Para 2 & 3 for descriptors. Look for specific literary traditions mentioned in the text.
Discuss the strategy with students.

IDENTIFICATION

TASK 1 | Genre Check

Decide if this is horror, sci-fi, or comedy. (Scan 'About the Author' p.144)
Classic horror storyComedy
BiographyEarly science fiction
History bookTravel writing
Monitor student progress.

ANSWER 1

Classic horror story & Early science fiction
[Para 3] 'often called the first science fiction novel... follows the Gothic tradition.'

Mary Shelley combined old scary 'Gothic' elements with new scientific ideas to create something completely new.
Discuss the answer with the class.

HOW TO: Scan for Bio

Scan Facts: Don't read every word! Find the names and years first. Where was Mary born? Where was she in 1816?
Discuss the strategy with students.

SCANNING

TASK 2 | The Idea

Mary Shelley Profile

WHEN
?

?
HOW
?

Scan Paras 1-2 for when, where and how Mary got the idea.

Monitor student progress.

ANSWER 2

WHEN: Summer 1816 | WHERE: Near Geneva | HOW: A powerful vision
[Para 2] 'stormy night in the summer of 1816... staying with... Lord Byron near Geneva... had a powerful vision'

Mary was only 19 when she had the vision during a ghost story competition with friends.
Discuss the answer with the class.
PHASE TWO

New Words

Let's master 5 tricky words so the story is easy to understand. Ready?

Moving to next section.

MAST

Phoneme /mæst/
Context "Victor built a 150-meter metal mast above his laboratory to catch the lightning."

AWFUL

Phoneme /ˈɔːfəl/
Context "Victor looked at the creature's thin, yellow skin and saw an awful smile on its face."

IRRESPONSIBLE

Phoneme /ˌɪrɪˈspɒnsəbl̩/
Context "Victor was irresponsible because he forgot about his family and letters for two years."

OBSESSIVE

Phoneme /əbˈsesɪv/
Context "Victor's work was obsessive; he worked every day and night without a single holiday."

RECKLESS

Phoneme /ˈrekləs/
Context "Instead of being careful, Victor's reckless use of electricity caused a huge disaster."

TASK 3 | Correct Order

1
E. He met Professor Waldman.
2
D. He learned about death in hospitals.
3
B. He was given his own laboratory.
4
A. He worked hard on his machine.
5
F. The electricity brought the creature to life.
6
C. He woke up and saw the creature.
Notice how Victor's ambition led him from education to isolation.

ANSWER 3

E -> D -> B -> A -> F -> C
[Para 1] Met Waldman → [Para 5] Learned about death → [Para 8] Given laboratory → [Para 4] Two years work → [Para 17] Body came alive → [Para 20] Woke to see creature.

Victor's journey: First Waldman inspired him, then he studied death, got a lab, worked obsessively, succeeded with electricity, and finally faced his creation in fear.
Discuss the answer with the class.
PHASE FOUR

The Lessons

Now we know the plot, let's look closer at Victor's big mistakes.

Moving to next section.

STRATEGY: Probing the Protagonist

WHAT: Analyzing 'Character Flaws' (Hubris).
WHY: To understand how Victor’s internal choices drive the external tragedy.
HOW: Scan the text for descriptors of Victor’s work habits and decisions (Page 147).
Discuss the strategy with students.

ANALYSIS

TASK 8 | Victor's Flaws

Which THREE words describe Victor's bad character? (Page 147)
AmbitiousObsessive
RecklessBrave
IrresponsibleSelfish
Monitor student progress.

ANSWER 8

Obsessive, Irresponsible, and Reckless
[Page 147] 'Victor's flawed character leads him to take the disastrous path...' The text identifies these three specific character flaws.

Victor was obsessive (worked without holidays), irresponsible (ignored his family), and reckless (used dangerous electricity without thinking).
Discuss the answer with the class.

STRATEGY: Identifying Themes

WHAT: Discovering the 'Moral of the Story'.
WHY: To connect the character's actions to universal warnings.
HOW: Look for paragraphs where the author addresses the reader directly (Page 147).
Discuss the strategy with students.

THEMES

TASK 9 | Big Ideas

Which TWO themes does Mary Shelley want us to think about? (Page 147)
Love conquers allDangerous Knowledge
MoralityTechnology is evil
Monitor student progress.

ANSWER 9

Dangerous Knowledge & Morality
[Page 147] 'dangerous and forbidden knowledge' and 'morals and distinguishing right from wrong'

Shelley warns us: some knowledge is dangerous, and we must always ask 'is this right?' before we act.
Discuss the answer with the class.
